title: 107_s1625
content: The Children's Health Equity Act of 2001 allows for up to 4 state waivers to use Title XXI allotments to increase Medicaid children's enrollment. In this section, key definitions include "child," "child health assistance," "enhanced FMAP," "Federal medical assistance percentage," and "poverty line" as defined under the Social Security Act. The terms "Federal medical assistance percentage," "poverty line," "Secretary," and "State child health plan" are defined under the Social Security Act. The Secretary is authorized to approve up to 4 waiver applications for states meeting specified requirements to receive payments. The Secretary can approve up to 4 waiver applications for states meeting specific requirements to receive payments under the Social Security Act. States must have the highest income eligibility standard allowed under title XXI, accept applications for all children, and provide benefits to all children in the state. The state must have the highest income eligibility standard under title XXI, accept all children's applications without limitations, and provide benefits to all eligible children statewide. For children below 200 percent of the poverty line, the state cannot impose numerical limitations or waiting lists for child health assistance. Additionally, the state must implement at least 4 specific policies and procedures. The state must have the highest income eligibility standard under title XXI and accept all children's applications without limitations. For children below 200 percent of the poverty line, the state cannot impose numerical limitations or waiting lists for child health assistance. Additionally, the state must implement at least 4 specific policies and procedures related to coverage of children under titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act. The State must use a uniform application form for eligibility under titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act, eliminate asset tests for children, and adopt 12-month continuous enrollment for children's eligibility. The State must adopt 12-month continuous enrollment for children's eligibility under title XXI of the Social Security Act, with the same verification and redetermination policies for initial eligibility determinations and redeterminations. The State must adopt 12-month continuous enrollment for children's eligibility under title XXI of the Social Security Act, with the same verification and redetermination policies for initial eligibility determinations and redeterminations. Additionally, the State must provide for outstationing enrollment staff for processing applications for benefits under title XXI and children under title XIX. The State must provide outstationing enrollment staff for processing applications for benefits under titles XIX and XXI at designated healthcare facilities. Payment authorized for States with a waiver approved under section 1905(l)(2)(B) of the Social Security Act to receive funding from the Secretary under section 2104 for their State child health plan. The Secretary shall pay the State an amount from its allotment under section 2104 of the Social Security Act for medical assistance for children in fiscal years, based on expenditures in 1995 and the current fiscal year. The Secretary determines total medical assistance expenditures for children in the State for fiscal year 1995. The bonus amount is calculated based on the difference in expenditures. The bonus amount for a fiscal year is calculated based on the total amount determined under subparagraph (C) and the difference between the enhanced FMAP and the Federal medical assistance percentage for that State. Children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act are included in this calculation. Children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act are described as those with family income exceeding the highest eligibility level under the State plan and would be considered disabled under section 1614(a)(3)(C) of the Social Security Act. Children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act are those with family income exceeding the highest eligibility level under the State plan and considered disabled under section 1614(a)(3)(C) of the Act. Payments to the State under section 2105(a) of the Act for a fiscal year shall be made in a specific order for expenditures. Payments to the State under section 2105(a) of the Social Security Act for a fiscal year with an approved waiver shall be prioritized in the following order: (A) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(A), (B) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(B), (C) payment authorized under subsection (d)(1), (D) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(C), and (E) expenditures for items in paragraph (1)(D).
